The ECU uses this value to proactively adjust the injection quantity, ensuring that the idle speed remains stable when heavy electrical consumers (like seat heaters or window defrosters) are switched on.
Map.UseCase: Maintains idle refinement and prevents the engine from 'dipping' or stumbling under electrical load.
Map.TuningAdvice: Generally should not be touched. If you have installed a significantly higher-output alternator, this map may need adjustment to maintain perfect idle stability.

Map.Title: AC Torque Compensation (mrwKLMD_KF)
Map.Description: This map defines the mechanical torque load placed on the engine by the air conditioning compressor. The ECU uses this value to adjust the idle speed controller and the anti-jerk logic, ensuring that the engine does not stumble or stall when the AC clutch engages or when refrigerant pressure is high.
Map.UseCase: Maintains idle stability and drivability when the air conditioning is active.
Map.TuningAdvice: Usually left stock. If you have installed a non-standard AC compressor or have significantly lightened the flywheel, you may need to adjust these values to maintain a smooth idle.

Map.Title: Active Motor Mount Control (mlwTW_KF)
Map.Description: Controls the pulse-width modulation (PWM) signal sent to active (switchable) engine mounts. The ECU adjusts the stiffness of the mounts based on engine speed and coolant temperature to minimize the transmission of vibrations to the vehicle chassis, especially at idle.
Map.UseCase: Used to restore factory-like refinement if the engine has become more 'vibrant' due to tuning or if aftermarket mounts are installed.
Map.TuningAdvice: Tuners often leave this stock. However, if you experience excessive cabin vibration at specific RPMs, adjusting the duty cycle can help 'tune out' the resonance.

Map.Title: AC Compressor Min Switch-Off Time (klwTMIN_KF)
Map.Description: This characteristic defines the minimum time the air conditioning compressor must remain off once it has been deactivated. This 'anti-cycling' logic protects the AC clutch and compressor from mechanical damage caused by rapid engagement and disengagement during high-load driving.
Map.UseCase: Protects the AC system hardware during aggressive driving where the ECU may frequently cut the AC load.
Map.TuningAdvice: Do not decrease this value. Increasing it can provide additional protection if the AC system is showing signs of premature wear in a tuned vehicle.

Map.Title: Misfire Detection Sensitivity (mrwZUE_KF)
Map.Description: This map defines the thresholds for engine speed 'roughness' used to detect misfires. The ECU monitors the acceleration of the crankshaft after each firing event; if the acceleration is below these thresholds, the ECU flags a misfire. This is critical for EOBD compliance and engine protection.
Map.UseCase: Diagnostic monitoring of combustion quality.
Map.TuningAdvice: Do not modify. Lowering these thresholds will make the ECU blind to misfires, potentially leading to engine damage. Raising them may cause 'false positive' misfire codes, especially if a lightened flywheel is installed.

Map.Title: Fuel Cooling Pump Control (kuwKK_KF)
Map.Description: Controls the activation and duty cycle of the fuel cooling system. PD engines return very hot fuel to the tank; this map ensures the fuel is cooled sufficiently to protect the fuel tank structure and maintain the lubricity of the diesel fuel for the high-pressure pump.
Map.UseCase: Thermal management of the fuel system during high-load or high-ambient temperature operation.
Map.TuningAdvice: Usually left stock. If you are running very high injection pressures or large nozzles that generate more heat, you may want to trigger the cooling pump earlier to keep fuel temperatures stable.

Map.Title: Electric Lift Pump Control (mrwEKP_KL)
Map.Description: This characteristic line manages the operation of the electric fuel lift pump located in the fuel tank. It ensures that the tandem pump on the cylinder head is always supplied with a steady flow of fuel, particularly during the start phase and under high engine load.
Map.UseCase: Ensuring fuel supply reliability across the RPM and load range.
Map.TuningAdvice: Usually left stock. If you have upgraded to a high-flow lift pump, this map may need adjustment to ensure the pump is not over-driven or causing excessive pressure in the return lines.

Map.Title: Tank Shut-off Valve (TAV) Logic (mrwTAV_KL)
Map.Description: Defines the logic for the safety shut-off valve in the fuel tank. This valve is designed to immediately cut the fuel supply in the event of a detected crash (via the airbag signal) or a major system failure, preventing fuel from feeding a fire.
Map.UseCase: Safety-critical fuel system isolation.
Map.TuningAdvice: Do not modify. This is a primary safety feature of the vehicle. Disabling or delaying this valve can have life-threatening consequences in the event of an accident.

Map.Title: Gear-Dependent Torque/Quantity Limits (mrwM_EBGxKL)
Map.Description: A series of characteristic lines (one for each gear) that define the maximum allowable torque or injection quantity. These are primarily used to protect the transmission and drivetrain components from excessive stress, particularly in lower gears where the torque multiplication is highest.
Map.UseCase: Limiting torque in 1st and 2nd gear to prevent gearbox failure or excessive wheel spin.
Map.TuningAdvice: When increasing power, these limits must be raised proportionally. However, be cautious with 1st and 2nd gear limits to avoid stripping gears or damaging the differential.

Map.Title: CVT Transmission Torque Limit (mrwM_ECVTKL)
Map.Description: This characteristic line is specific to vehicles equipped with a Continuously Variable Transmission (CVT). It defines the maximum engine torque allowed to ensure the CVT belt does not slip and the variator pulleys are not overloaded.
Map.UseCase: Drivetrain protection for CVT-equipped VAG models (e.g., early Multitronic systems).
Map.TuningAdvice: Exercise extreme caution. CVT transmissions are very sensitive to torque increases. Exceeding the factory limits often leads to rapid belt wear or total transmission failure.
